quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Welsh and Following
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, rooms, hwyl. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Rooms in Japanese houses and apartments are typically measured by which of the following?

options.text: The number of tatami mats in the room
The number of futons that will fit in the room

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The number of tatami mats in the room

questions.question: In America, horror films are often released in October, to cash in on the Halloween season. In Japan, horror films are a staple of which season?
The Japanese call Mount Fuji Fuji-san. San refers to which of the following?

options.text: A suffix adopted from WWII American troops
A reading of the Chinese character that means mountain
The Japanese word for the number three
A term of respect, like the san that follows Japanese names

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: A reading of the Chinese character that means mountain

questions.question: Under what name is Thomas Woodward better known?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tom Jones

questions.question: In America, it is not unusual to find buildings with no thirteenth floor. In Japan, which floor of a hotel might one find missing?
In the America Bowl at Wembley stadium in 1987, the Welsh Full Back Paul Thorburn made a guest appearance for which NFL team?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: L. A. Rams

questions.question: There is no word for no in the Japanese language.
The Welsh term hwyl, which means good spirit and enthusiasm, is rather similar to the Irish term craic.
Sushi, the icon of Japanese cuisine, is characterized by which of the following?

options.text: Soy based dipping sauces and wasabi

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Specially prepared rice

questions.question: The Japanese word baitoh (pronounced BUY-toe) means part time job and is adapted from which language?
In which South American country is there a small population that speaks only Spanish and Welsh?
The Welsh are renowned for singing. One of their popular hymns is known in Welsh as Cwm Rhondda. By what name is it more commonly referred to in English?

options.text: When you come home again to Wales

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bread of Heaven

questions.question: What abbreviation is used for a member of the Welsh Assembly?
Before money existed, people obtained goods this way.
Japanese weddings are usually small family affairs.

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Money and Banknotes
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, submarines, bills. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The first money appeared around 1,200 BC in the form of this.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Oyster shells

questions.question: Paper money were very convenient and much used. This led to their devaluation and they disappeared around this year.
Oyster shells were used as money until this time.

options.text: Until the middle of the 20th century

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Until the middle of the 20th century

questions.question: This British submarine, under the command of lieutenant-commander Malcolm David Wanklyn, completed 24 patrols, sinking around 120,000 tons of enemy shipping.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: HMS Upholder (P37)

questions.question: The first European metal coins, which resembled modern currency were made of this.
American Indians used beaded shells as money. They called them this.
Operation Deadlight was the code name for the scuttling of U-boats surrendered to the Allies after the defeat of Germany, near the end of World War II. How many U-boats were scuttled?
In 1942, during World War II, RMS Laconia was sunk by what type of U-boat?
This successful Russian submarine, used during World War II, was responsible for the sinking of the German refugee transport Goya in April 1945.
Which of these is not a class of American submarines, used during World War II?
The first paper bills (banknotes) appeared in this year.
The first banknotes were made of this.
This is when the first metal coins appeared.
The first bills (banknotes) appeared in this country.
What is the official state animal of Connecticut?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The sperm whale

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Connecticut and Year
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, nutmeg, title. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The University of Connecticut won both the mens and womens NCAA basketball championships in the same year.
What is the state song of Connecticut?

options.text: Long Live the Glories of  Old Connecticut

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Yankee Doodle

questions.question: The Brook Farm area was a settlement of intellectuals on the outskirts of Hartford.  Among its distinguished residents were Harriet Beecher Stowe and this author.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mark Twain

questions.question: Connecticut is the home of the Charter Oak.
Who established the colony of Connecticut in 1636?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Thomas Hooker

questions.question: Mystic Seaport was the center of the whaling industry in Connecticut.
When was the title Man of the Year changed to Person of the Year?
Why is Connecticut sometimes referred to as The Nutmeg State?

options.text: Nutmeg grows wild in Southern New England and is the state plant of Connecticut.
New Englanders used to flavor all their cooking with nutmeg.
Yankee peddlers used to sell wooden nutmegs and try to pawn them off as the real thing.
The nutmeg spice was one of Connecticuts major trade commodities.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Yankee peddlers used to sell wooden nutmegs and try to pawn them off as the real thing.

questions.question: One of the statesmen on the Committee that drafted the Declaration of Independence was the delegate from Connecticut. What was his name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Roger Sherman

questions.question: When did Time magazine begin selecting Man of the Year?
Foxwoods Resort Casino, famous as the biggest casino in the world, is located in Southeastern Connecticut.
What is the capital city of Connecticut?
Who was selected as Time magazines first Man of the Year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Charles Lindbergh

questions.question: What is the oldest university in Connecticut?
Which of these was one of the early heroes of the American Revolution who was executed by the British?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nathan Hale

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Year and Time
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, world, woman. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Who was the first woman to win Time magazines title Man of the Year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bessie Wallis Warfield Spencer Simpson

questions.question: He was the first person involved in the automobile industry to win Time magazines title Man (or Person) of the Year.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Walter Percy Chrysler

questions.question: This American jurist won Time magazines Man of the Year award in 1973 and was influential in getting rid of the man who won the award in 1971.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: John Sirica

questions.question: He was the first European to be selected Man of the Year by Time magazine. He was also the first winner to be executed in his country for treason.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pierre Laval

questions.question: Find the correct statement about Dwight David Eisenhower.

options.text: He never won Time magazines Man of the Year award.
He was the first person to win Time magazines Man of the Year award three times.
He won Time magazines Man of the Year award twice as US President.
He won Time magazines Man of the Year award once as President and once before he was President.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He won Time magazines Man of the Year award once as President and once before he was President.

questions.question: Who was the first non-American to be granted Time magazines title Man of the Year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mahatma Gandhi

questions.question: In 1986 this brave woman won Time magazines Man of the Year award. Three years earlier she witnessed the assassination of her husband.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Corazon C. Aquino

questions.question: Who was the first person to be chosen Man (or Person) of the Year three times?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Franklin Delano Roosevelt

questions.question: Since the inception of the Man of the Year award through 2007, every sitting US President was chosen Man of the Year.
This two-time winner of Time magazines Man of the Year title came up with a plan to rebuild Europe after World War II.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: George Marshall

questions.question: He was the first person chosen for Time magazines Man of the Year award two years in a row.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Richard M. Nixon

questions.question: In 1968 the Apollo astronauts were chosen for Time magazines Man of the Year award. Who were they ?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Anders, Borman, Lovell

questions.question: Who was Time magazines first Man of the Year to be under 26 years old?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Charles Lindbergh

questions.question: Joseph Stalin was selected as Time magazines Man (or Person) of the Year more than once.
When he was voted Man of the Year his photograph was not put on the cover of Time magazine.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Adolph Hitler

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Continent and Planet
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, peak, bird. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The name of which continent is believed to mean dust, cave, and sunny according to various theories on the origin of its name?
She was the first Queen to win Time magazines title Man of the Year.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Queen Elizabeth II

questions.question: What is the largest and most populous continent on the planet?
On which two continents are there cities named Darwin?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: North America and Australia

questions.question: This man, named Person of the Year by Time magazine in 2001, stood tall after the 9/11 and inspired his city to get  through the terrible attack.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rudy Giuliani

questions.question: The longest river in the world is located on this continent, which is the second largest on the planet.
In 1956 the Freedom Fighters of this country won Time magazines Man of the Year award.
The Emu, the second-largest bird living on the planet, is indigenous to this continent.
On what continent is the Quechua language spoken by its indigenous peoples?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: South America

questions.question: Cynthia Cooper, Coleen Rowley, and Sherron Watkins were granted Time magazines Person of the Year award. Under what title did they win?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Whistleblowers

questions.question: The dishes Tom yum soup, hummus, chicken tikka and Nasi goreng belong to the cuisine of what continent?
Valletta is the capital city of an island country belonging to the territory of this continent.
Which is the highest peak in the Canadian Rockies?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mt. Robson

questions.question: Victoria Land is a region located on this continent.
Mount McKinley, or Denali, is the highest mountain peak on this continent.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: North America

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Canada and Poland
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, arrow, land. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: How many provinces does Canada comprise?
What government agency was Newsweek Magazines CW 2008 referring to when they wrote Asleep at the regulatory switch?
Which explorer sailed to the mouth of the Mississippi River and claimed it for France?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: La Salle

questions.question: The arrow points up for this lady who, according to Newsweeks CW 2008, has brains, experience and a great work ethic. Who is Barack Obamas choice for U. S. Secretary of State?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hillary Clinton

questions.question: Arrow down. Who according to Newsweeks CW 2008 is ill-informed, inarticulate shopaholic that has an ego bigger than Alaska?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sarah Palin

questions.question: The name Canada comes from the St. Lawrence Iroquoian word, kanata. What does it mean in English?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: village, settlement

questions.question: Poland was one of the first countries to have a constitution (1791). Which constitution/s was/were passed earlier than the Polish one?
Which of the following countries is smaller (in terms of land area) than Poland?
Who set up the first permanent settlement in North America?
Paul Martin served as President of Canada.
Which is the longest river flowing through Poland?
Is Canadas national anthem titled O Canada?
Sir Francis Drakes captained an English galleon called the Golden Phoenix.
Who was the first President of Poland?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gabirel Narutowicz

questions.question: This sea captain, who was second-in-command of the English fleet against the Spanish Armada, claimed for the Queen a North American territory called New Albion.
